channel.title: Bloomberg Markets

item.title: Dollar Weaker as Traders Mull Moody’s US Downgrade: Markets Wrap
item.description: The dollar edged lower and US equity futures slipped in early trading Monday as fiscal concerns mounted over Treasuries and the trajectory of US borrowing.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Burgess

media:content.media:description: An American flag is displayed outside the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., on Monday, July 2, 2018. U.S. stocks fell on lower than normal volume as investors waved off stronger than expected manufacturing numbers and focused on fears of increasing global trade tensions.

item.title: Polish Ballot Set to Jolt Zloty as Pro-EU Front-Runner Pressured
item.description: A stronger-than-expected showing by opposition populists in the first round of Poland’s presidential election will test investor appetite for the country’s assets.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski, Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Rafal Trzaskowski, mayor of Warsaw, center, waves a Polish flag during an election night rally in Sandomierz, Poland, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. Trzaskowski, the centrist Warsaw mayor, and Karol Nawrocki, a pro-Donald Trump nationalist, came neck-and-neck in the first round of Poland's presidential election, according to an exit poll, in a blow to the pro-European government.

item.title: Investors Await Another Monday Jolt After Moody’s Downgrades US
item.description: Investors face yet another bumpy start to the trading week, although it’s mounting concern over US debt rather than tariffs likely generating the volatility this time.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova, Carmen Reinicke, Anya Andrianova

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: Singapore Bourse Risks Further Delistings Despite New Proposals
item.description: Singapore’s move to simplify the initial public offering process, part of recent measures to boost its moribund equities market, is unlikely to reverse a yearslong trend of delistings crowding out new listings, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: John Cheng, Justina T Lee

media:content.media:description: A person riding an escalator is reflected at the Singapore Exchange Ltd. (SGX) headquarters in Singapore, on Tuesday, Feb. 7, 2023. SGX is scheduled to release earnings results on Feb. 9.

item.title: Five Key Charts to Watch in Global Commodity Markets This Week
item.description: The scrap copper industry in the US is hustling to move piled up supplies over to China now that the two superpowers have put their trade dispute on a temporary pause. South Korea’s homegrown atomic technology has the world’s attention. And, US Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s desire for diet changes has the potential to impact the global food supply chain.
item.dc:creator: Jack Wittels, Alex Longley, Yvonne Yue Li, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: Customers refuel at a Love's gas station in Dallas, Texas, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Oil has trended lower since late January due to escalating trade frictions and plans by OPEC+ to keep boosting idled supply, but prices have moved away from their lows in the last couple of days.

item.title: Hope Springs in German C-Suites as Gloom Starts to Lift
item.description: A vibe shift is underway in Europe’s largest economy. Plus, the CFO of India’s Tata Communications discusses growth plans, geopolitics and more.
item.dc:creator: Nina Trentmann

media:content.media:description: German CFOs are cautiously optimistic that the country’s new government can get the economy back on track. Photo credit: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Midpoint of Trump Tariff Hiatus to Reveal Increasingly Unsettled World
item.description: Reports in the coming week may give the fullest reading to date of how major economies are faring with trade disruptions, halfway through President Donald Trump’s 90-day hiatus on so-called reciprocal tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Idle gantry cranes at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Recent data showed a slump in trade across the Pacific Ocean, fueling worries that Trump's broad tariff agenda could hit American consumers with higher prices and fewer choices and spur a global downturn.

item.title: RBA Poised for ‘Hawkish Cut’ as US-China Reprieve Boosts Outlook
item.description: Australia’s central bank is set to lower interest rates for a second time this year as price pressures ease and US-China trade tensions take a pause, though lingering risks around both suggest the board will remain cautious on the policy path ahead.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey, Matthew Burgess

media:content.media:description: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) building in Sydney, Australia, on Friday, July 14, 2023. Australia's treasurer announced that Michele Bullock will be the new Reserve Bank governor when incumbent Philip Lowes term expires in September, becoming the first woman to helm the nations central bank.

item.title: NYC Bankers Who Live in NJ Game Out Commute as Rail Strike Upends RTO Plans
item.description: The initiative by banks and other employers in New York to bring back workers to the office is being undermined by an unexpected roadblock in a neighboring state.
item.dc:creator: Sri Taylor, Lauren Tara Lacapra, Josyana Joshua

media:content.media:description: Members of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen picket outside of the Hoboken Terminal during a strike in Hoboken, New Jersey, US, on Friday, May 16, 2025. New Jersey Transit locomotive engineers started striking early Friday, triggering a shutdown of the agency's rail service and disrupting travel for thousands of commuters.

item.title: Buffett to Skip Stage at 2026 Annual Meeting, Omaha Paper Says
item.description: Warren Buffett will not take the stage at the Berkshire Hathaway 2026 annual meeting, preferring instead to let his successor have the spotlight after he retires, the Omaha World-Herald reported.
item.dc:creator: Maria Paula Mijares Torres

media:content.media:description: Warren Buffett, chairman and chief executive officer of Berkshire Hathaway Inc., speaks at the Goldman Sachs 10,000 Small Businesses Summit in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Tuesday, Feb. 13, 2018. Goldman's 10,000 Small Businesses is an investment that brings economic opportunity and assists entrepreneurs to create jobs by providing better access to education, capital and business support services.

item.title: Inspire Medical CEO on Improving Patient Outcomes
item.description: Tim Herbert, Founder, Chairman, President and CEO of publicly traded Inspire Medical Systems, discusses the company's breakthrough technology that helps people suffering from obstructive sleep apnea, as well as the company's strong quarterly earnings amid headwinds facing the broader health care industry. Tim speaks with Tim Stenovec and Emily Graffeo on Bloomberg Businessweek Daily. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US States Likely to Defy US Downgrade to Keep Top Credit Ratings
item.description: US states from Florida to North Carolina and Texas would likely hold onto top-notch credit scores from Moody’s Ratings, mostly because they’re in better fiscal shape than the federal government itself.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Scott Carpenter

media:content.media:description: The Florida State Capitol Complex in Tallahassee, Florida.

item.title: China-US Trade Truce Prompts Nations to Consider Tougher Tactics
item.description: China’s defiant stance in negotiating a tariff truce with the US has convinced some countries they need to take a tougher position in their own trade talks with the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump during a Congressional resolution signing in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 9.

item.title: UniCredit Asks Regulator for More Time in BPM Bid, Corriere Says
item.description: UniCredit SpA asked Italy’s market regulator Consob to suspend its takeover bid for Banco BPM SpA to give it time to negotiate with the government over conditions imposed on the deal, newspaper Il Corriere della Sera reported.
item.dc:creator: Sonia Sirletti

media:content.media:description: A UniCredit SpA bank logo at a company's bank branch in Turin, Italy, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Banco BPM SpA said its takeover offer for Anima Holding SpA has been accepted by enough of the asset manager’s shareholders to meet the minimum threshold it has set.

item.title: French Regulator Tells Airlines to Cut Orly Flights After Glitch
item.description: France’s civil aviation regulator asked airlines to reduce their flight schedules at Paris-Orly airport by 40% by the end of Sunday after air traffic control systems suffered a failure.
item.dc:creator: Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: Passengers in the departures hall at Paris-Orly Airport, operated by Aeroports de Paris, in Paris, France, on Tuesday, Feb. 27, 2024. Air France-KLM report earnings on Feb. 29.

item.title: Adams Issues Brooklyn Bridge Ship Collision Statement
item.description: New York City Mayor Eric Adams spoke on Sunday to after a Mexican naval vessel carrying 277 people scraped the bottom of the Brooklyn Bridge on Saturday evening, leaving two crew members dead and several others injured. He gave condolences to the family members saying "They are properly being taken care of." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Army Secretary Driscoll: 'We Are Doing the Right Thing'
item.description: An update on a story we told in November about the state of the defense industry. US Army Secretary Daniel Driscoll tells us about the Trump administration's approach to the US army’s budget, including funding more defense tech start-ups. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Wall Street Banks Say Emerging Markets’ Wasted Years Are Over
item.description: Wall Street’s emerging-market faithful are finally seeing better returns after missing out for years as US stocks soared.
item.dc:creator: Selcuk Gokoluk

media:content.media:description: Exchange rate information displayed outside a currency exchange office in Mexico City, Mexico, on Tuesday, Feb. 4, 2025. The Mexican peso led a rebound in broad currency markets while the dollar all but erased gains on news US tariffs on Mexico would be delayed for one month.

item.title: What’s Happening in EM: Wall Street Sees EM Bull Case (Podcast)
item.description: Selcuk Gokoluk and Zijia Song discuss why emerging markets stocks have beat S&P 500 index this year and investors’ bullish calls for EM to continue to outperform.
item.dc:creator: Zijia Song

item.title: Big Tech Goes From Stock Market’s Safest Bet to Biggest Question
item.description: For most of the past decade, a handful of high-flying technology companies have pushed the US stock market to record highs and become cornerstones of investment portfolios. But that’s collapsed this year.
item.dc:creator: Jeran Wittenstein, Carmen Reinicke

media:content.media:description: The Nasdaq MarketSite in New York, US, on Monday, Sept. 16, 2024. Wall Street traders gearing up for this week's Federal Reserve decision kept driving a rotation out of the tech megacaps that have powered the bull market in stocks.

item.title: Dubai’s Red-Hot Real Estate Is Starting to Attract Big Name Backers
item.description: Dubai’s real estate market - where property values have surged 70% in the last four years - is starting to entice a slew of new Wall Street investors.
item.dc:creator: Zainab Fattah

media:content.media:description: The Burj Khalifa, center, from the Dubai International Financial Centre.

item.title: Portugal Eases Limits on Power Imports From Spain After Blackout
item.description: Portugal will continue to ease limits on the electricity interconnection capacity for imports from Spain after trading between the two countries was halted last month due to a blackout.
item.dc:creator: Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: A traffic light off due to a major blackout in Lisbon, Portugal, on Monday, April 28, 2025. Public transport, traffic lights and phone services were mostly down in parts of Madrid, Barcelona and Lisbon due to the outage, while trains were mostly halted.

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s Sabic Is Said to Explore IPO of Its Gas Business
item.description: Saudi Arabian chemicals giant Sabic is exploring an initial public offering of its gas business, according to people familiar with the matter, amid a broader operational review.
item.dc:creator: Laura Gardner Cuesta, Matthew Martin, Nicolas Parasie

item.title: ECB’s Lagarde Says Euro’s Strength Is Counterintuitive, But Justified
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde said the recent rise of the euro against the dollar is a consequence of US President Donald Trump’s erratic policies and an opportunity for Europe.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Francois De Beaupuy

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Portugal Holds Third Election in Three Years: What to Watch
item.description: Portugal holds its third election in as many years on Sunday, after Prime Minister Luis Montenegro’s minority government lost a confidence vote in parliament in March.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida, Joao Lima

media:content.media:description: Luis Montenegro, Portugal's prime minister, center, at a street rally on May 16. Photographer: Patricia de Melo Moreira/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: India Restricts Some Imports from Bangladesh as Ties Suffer
item.description: India imposed curbs on imports of ready-made garments and processed food from Bangladesh, as relations between the two neighbors turned sour in recent months.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: The land port restrictions may further affect the ties between the two nations as India was Bangladesh’s third-biggest trading partner in 2024.

item.title: Timing Not Right for China Home-Sales Overhaul: State Media
item.description: The timing for a nationwide housing market reform that would only allow developers to sell completed properties is “not mature,” according to China Real Estate Business, an outlet managed by China’s Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development.
item.dc:creator: Venus Feng

item.title: New CLO Managers Are Pouring Into the Market
item.description: A spate of hedge funds and asset managers are diving into the $1.3 trillion CLO market with debut vehicles, fueling demand for new leveraged loans and pushing up prices for older ones.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Arroyo, Rachel Graf, Amedeo Goria

item.title: Trump Administration Drops Southwest Scheduling Lawsuit
item.description: The Trump administration dropped a lawsuit against Southwest Airlines Co. that accused the airline of setting unrealistic flight schedules that led to chronic delays.
item.dc:creator: Robert Burnson

media:content.media:description: A ramp agents walks under the wing of a Southwest Airlines Boeing 737-700 airplane as it is pushed back from the gate for departure at Baltimore-Washington Airport (BWI) in Baltimore, Maryland, US, on Friday, April 12, 2024. Southwest Airlines Co. is scheduled to release earnings figures on April 25.

item.title: NJ Transit CEO Speaks Before Meeting Union Amid Strike
item.description: NJ Transit CEO Kris Kolluri held a presser before meeting with union on Saturday. He a said he appreciates their contribution to the agency and that his objective is to "make sure they get back to work." (Source: Bloomberg)
